intro: Helianthus carolinianus, commonly known as the Carolina sunflower, is a species of flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that consist of both ray and disk flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 1 to 3 feet and features bright yellow petals surrounding a central cluster of smaller flowers. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are hairy and often branched. The Carolina sunflower is known for its ability to thrive in a variety of soil types and is often found in open fields, roadsides, and disturbed areas.
